The patient is interested in evaluation because he is on the move with his work and would like it taken care of. He has no voiding complaints and no history of sexually transmitted diseases. His employment is that he does dynamite work and actually putting in the dynamite in large holes for destroying ground to that pipeline can be laid. He travels to anywhere for his work. He is married with one son. FAMILY HISTORY: Negative for prostate cancer, kidney cancer, bladder cancer, enlarged prostate or kidney disease. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Negative for tremors, headaches, dizzy spells, numbness, tingling, feeling hot or cold, tired or sluggishness, abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting, indigestion, heartburn, fevers, chills, weight loss, wheezing, frequent cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, varicose veins, high blood pressure, skin rash, joint pain, ear infections, sore throat, sinus problems, hay fever, blood clotting problems, depressive affect or eye problems. layman:
Thank you for letting me help with the evaluation of the patient. He is a 44‑year‑old man who has had a skin lesion on his penis for about a year. He has called it a “skin tag” before. He says it never hurts, has never been hit or bled, and he wants it checked because his job requires him to travel a lot. He has no problems with urination and has never had a sexually transmitted disease.

**Past medical history:** None.  
**Past surgical history:** Back surgery with a fusion at the L5‑S1 level.  
**Medications:** He takes Percocet occasionally for back pain.  
**Allergies:** None.  

**Social history:** He smokes. He drinks alcohol rarely. He works with dynamite, placing it in large holes to break ground for pipelines. He travels for work. He is married with one son.

**Family history:** No family history of prostate, kidney, or bladder cancer, enlarged prostate, or kidney disease.

**Review of systems:** He reports no tremors, headaches, dizziness, numbness, tingling, feeling too hot or cold, fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, indigestion, heartburn, fever, chills, weight loss, wheezing, cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, varicose veins, high blood pressure, skin rash, joint pain, ear infections, sore throat, sinus problems, hay fever, blood clotting problems, depression, or eye problems.

**Physical exam:**  
- Temperature: normal.  
- Vital signs: stable.  
- Weight: 177 lbs. Height: 5 ft 8 in. Blood pressure: 144/66.  
- He looks healthy, alert, and oriented.  
- Heart: regular rate and rhythm.  
- Lungs: clear.  
- Abdomen: soft and not tender.  
- Penis: circumcised. He has a pedunculated, cauliflower‑like lesion on the back of the penis at the 12 o’clock position. It is obvious. He also has a mildly raised brown spot that has been there his whole life and has not changed.  
- Testicles: descended on both sides. No masses.

**Assessment and plan:**  
The lesion is most likely molluscum contagiosum (genital warts) caused by HPV. I explained that it is a viral infection that can have a long incubation period and is probably sexually transmitted. I advised him to use protection in the future to reduce the chance of spreading it.  

For treatment, I mentioned a cream called Condylox that could take up to a month to work. I also offered CO₂ laser therapy, an outpatient procedure. He wants a quick and effective option, so he chose the CO₂ laser. I told him that the recurrence rate can be as high as 20% even after removing the lesions. He understood the risk and decided to proceed. The main risks are those that come with laser treatment, such as accidental injury. He agreed to go ahead.
